script.description: Defines a grid of rays in the yz plane at x=10. The extent of the grid in the y direction is -2 to 2; the extent in the z direction is -5 to 5. Two hundred rays are generated. This is a non-equally spaced grid.

script.name: GRID_WINDOW.inr
script.title: Using the GRID WINDOW Command
script.description: Creates a rectangular raster-type ray grid using the current WINDOW and PIXELS settings.

script.name: GRIN_ARRAY01.inr
script.title: Array of GRINs
script.description: Example of a GRIN lens array. Features a bi-planer lens where the GRIN is actually doing the focusing.

script.name: grin_dispersive.inr
script.title: Dispersive GRIN Systems
script.description: Modeling a dispersive GRIN system. In this case, it's a gradient index photographic lens (polychromatic version). This is only a partial file.

script.name: grin_lens01.inr
script.title: Grin Lens Optimization
script.description: A GRIN lens optimized for best focus.

script.name: grin_lens02.inr
script.title: GRIN Photographic Lens
script.description: Gradient index photographic lens.

script.name: grin_radial01.inr
script.title: GRIN Medium with Radial Variation
script.description: Example of a GRIN refractive material. Trace a collimated source of rays through the material and display the TRACE, SPOTS, and ISOMETRIC graphics. Show the results in the 3D-Viewer.

script.name: grin_radial02.inr
script.title: Radial GRIN Fiber
script.description: Example of a GRIN refractive material. Trace a collimated source of rays through the material and do various plots of fiber and rays.

script.name: grin_radial03.inr
script.title: Radial GRIN Using a SECH Function
script.description: Example of a GRIN fiber using a Hyperbolic Secant function. Traces a collimated source of rays through the material and plots slices through the rod.

script.name: GRIN_Test.inr
script.title: GRIN Media
script.description: A demonstration of light bending through a gradient index material. Change the GRIN thickness or the step size to see the different effects in the plot.

script.name: group01.inr
script.title: Grouping Objects
script.description: Various ways of GROUPing objects.

script.name: group02.inr
script.title: Grouping Objects for Shifting/Rotating
script.description: Select groups of objects to shift and/or rotate. Nine elliptical surfaces are created. The first 3 are shifted and rotated. The second 3 are shifted and rotated. The last 3 are shifted. The plot shows the before and after.

script.name: grouping01.inr
script.title: Grouping Objects with Sources
script.description: How to group selected objects and sources so that they may be rotated and shifted together. This uses the SOURCES modifier of the GROUP command to add the desired sources to the group.

script.name: harvey_plot.inr
script.title: HARVEY PLOT Display
script.description: How to use PLOT option on HARVEY model and call up the display data for further analysis. The PIXELS command sets the resolution for these plots and the display data.

script.name: header_change.inr
script.title: Changing a Dump File Wavelength
script.description: Shows how to modify a display file header to change the wavelength setting. A ray file created with a DUMP command has the wavelength of the source saved in the header of the file. If these rays are used again for further ray tracing, they will remain at that wavelength. A new WAVELENGTH command before EMITTING DATA will not change that. The Header of the file needs modified to place a 0 in the first wavelength number. This allows the wavelength to be changed by the next WAVELENGTHS command. Of course the wavelength could be specified directly, but the former method allows the option of automating the process with a macro.

script.name: Header_Change02.inr
script.title: Changing Title of Field Plot or Picture
script.description: How to write a new sub-title to the current display file for subsequent plotting or for the PICTURE

script.name: Heliostat_Scatter_01.inr
script.title: Scatter Towards Array of Heliostats
script.description: The following script locates a source and specularly scatters light towards an array of heliostat mirrors. The position of the mirrors is located by x,y,z coordinates. Coordinates can be read from a text file or read in-line (currently). With the 4th data column, the mirrors are rotated about the Y-axis (easily modified for rotating about other axes).

script.name: HELIX01.inr
script.title: Use of the HELIX command
script.description: Create an EDGE HELIX and make it into an EMITTING ENTITY and an EMITTING OBJECT.

script.name: HEX_PYRAMID_ARRAY_CROSSED_ROOFS.inr
script.title: Hex pyramid array by bounded, crossed ROOFS
script.description: An ARRAY of hexagonal pyramids is made using crossed ROOF surfaces. The three ROOFs are mutually bounded to form the pyramids. Please note the possibility for ray leakage (see Help, ROOF command) (approx 3% measured) when directing rays on axis with the pyramids. This should not be a concern when intersecting with randomized ray directions.

script.name: Hex_Tube.inr
script.title: Hexagonal Tube with Surfaces
script.description: A method to make a hexagonal tube using a $DO loop. A simple formula is used to calculate the side dimensions so that bounding is unnecessary. A GROUP command may be used to apply further transformations from the origin.

script.name: HISTORY_Flux_Per_Angle.inr
script.title: Graphing Flux per Angle of any Object
script.description: An example showing how to use HISTORY PX to select out paths of rays hitting a surface for each degree over a specified angular range. A $ITER loop is used to create the display file of flux per angle using PX commands. A graph is easily plotted from the stored iter data. A parabola was examined here, but any surface could have been used.

script.name: History_Plot.inr
script.title: Plotting Ray Histories
script.description: Using HISTORY PLOT to plot the reverse trajectory of a selected ray path. The SAVE command must be invoked before the trace in order to have saved ray intersection data.

script.name: hoe1.inr
script.title: HOE Imported from Zemax
script.description: An HOE (Holographic Optical Element) imported from Zemax. The holographic surface used for the diffractive element is made with a multiple USERFUNC surface which calls a holographic function.

script.name: hoe2.inr
script.title: HOE by Two Point Sources
script.description: Define a function that is equal to the total optical path length along straight lines that connect the two points with a given point on the plane. The plane is assumed to be perpendicular to the z axis. A given point on the plane is given by the registers _1, _2, and _3 (_3 is always zero). The xyz coordinates of the first point are _4, _5, and _6, and the coordinates of the second point are _7, _8, and _9. After the function is defined, the three components of the gradient for the function are defined (the z component of the gradient is zero).

script.name: HORN_Array_01.inr
script.title: Array of HORNs Bounded by Planes
script.description: An Array of HORN Surfaces bounded by two planes.

script.name: IES_Data.inr
script.title: Writing an IES file
script.description: Creates a source and writes its properties to a standard IESNA photometric file (name.IES) of an angular distribution created by either a RADIANT command (A or C photometry where the polar axis becomes vertical) or a SPOTS DIR and ANGLES combination (B photometry). ASAP uses IES Standard LM-63-1995.

script.name: Immerse_Rays01.inr
script.title: Sources born in Different Media
script.description: Starting a source in a media other than vacuum/air, using the IMMERSE command.

script.name: Immerse_Rays02.inr
script.title: Complete Example using IMMERSE
script.description: Using IMMERSE to start rays inside another medium other than vacuum/air. In this case, the rays must be born in plastic, since the source is inside the LED. Even though the interfaces are 100% transmissive, the rays must exit into AIR before they hit the LENS_A interface. Otherwise, wrong-side errors will stop the rays from going further.

script.name: Integrating_Sphere01.inr
script.title: Importance Area Sampling
script.description: A model of an integrating sphere to show multiple random scatter. LEVEL and HALT are adjusted to allow many generations of scatter for a more accurate power calculation.

script.name: Integrating_Sphere02.inr
script.title: Integrating Sphere
script.description: A more detailed integrating sphere using a Lambertian surface scattering TOWARDS an edge. The RANDOM modifier is needed on the SCATTER MODEL command to make sure a seed ray gets generated to make all rays scatter toward the importance edge. With a LEVEL high enough and sufficient number of starting rays, the correct flux should be calculated for the exit hole.

script.name: interface01.inr
script.title: Reflective Interface
script.description: Various ways of defining reflective interfaces. The minus (-) sign prevents the transmitted ray from being traced.

script.name: interface02.inr
script.title: Refractive Interface
script.description: Several ways of defining refractive interfaces. The PLUS (+) sign prevents reflected rays from being traced.

script.name: INTERFACE_REPEAT.inr
script.title: Redefining OBJECT Properties
script.description: How to change the interface properties of the second object with a previously-defined object. In this case, the interface properties are changed to match the first object.

script.name: interfering_plane_waves.inr
script.title: Interfering Plane Waves
script.description: Two plane waves intersecting to show interfence. One is tipped relative the other.

script.name: INVERT01.inr
script.title: Use of the INVERT command
script.description: Create (2) identical edge points. Use ROTATE to see the effect. For second edge use INVERT before ROTATE. Note, there is no effect on the rotation of the edges, but the points are reordered as seen by PLOT EDGES

script.name: irradiance_vs_wavelength.inr
script.title: Plotting Irradiance vs. Wavelength
script.description: How to plot irradiance vs. wavelength for a polychromatic source. Uses $ITER to run raytraces at wavelength intervals over a thermal spectrum, saving the irradiance results to the iter.dis display file.

script.name: isometric.inr
script.title: ISOMETRIC Display Command
script.description: Create a 3-Dimensional plot of a SPOTS POSITION distribution file. Performed after a DISPLAY command. Does not modify display data. A Gaussian apodized grid is plotted.

script.name: Iter_Find_Lens_RC.inr
script.title: Modifying Lens RC with $ITER
script.description: The following uses the second form of $ITER to find the best Radius of Curvature of a lens to focus the rays at a specified target position. The lens is actually rebuilt with a new R of C value at each iteration (the object's associated LENS entity is redefined) and the XY deviations of the the rays at the target are tested for minimum. When a best minimum is found, the new R of C is printed along with the Centroid Z position, which should equal the Target Z position. It starts with a desired focus position of 60. This is where the target is placed. Change this number to view different results.

script.name: Iter_Focus_Find.inr
script.title: Finding Best Focus with $ITER
script.description: This demonstrates the second form of $ITER by finding the best focus of a singlet lens. A trace is performed at each iteration and the target repositioned until a minimum ray deviation is found. The technique of redefining a Surface and Object is used. This new position is printed and compared with the ASAP command, FOCUS MOVE, which is actually the easier way to perform this function. The Radius of Curvature for the lens may be changed to view a different set of results.

script.name: ITER_GENERAL_First_Form.inr
script.title: Modifying a GENERAL Polynomial Surface with ALTER
script.description: The following uses the first form of $ITER to plot changes to the Radius of Curvature of an optical surface made with GENERAL. The GENERAL polynomial is changed with ALTER at each iteration step.

script.name: Iter_Multiple_Var_Graphing01.inr
script.title: Plotting Multiple Iter Results in one Graph
script.description: A way to run multiple iterations on several variables, storing the data in one display file so they can be graphed separately or as a series.

script.name: ITER_OPTICAL_First_Form.inr
script.title: Modifying OPTICAL RC with $ITER
script.description: The following uses the first form of $ITER to graph the results of a range of Radius of Curvatures for an OPTICAL. The $ITER records the entire the entire range in ITER.DIS and leaves off where the minimum RofC was found. The OPTICAL is rebuilt with a new RofC at each iteration (the object's associated OPTICAL entity is redefined) and the XZ deviations of the the rays at the target are saved at each step. This is not as accurate as using the second form - see "ITER_OPTICAL_Second_Form.INR" where a more precise minimum may be found. This first form will simply step through the range as given, leaving it in the best step where the minimum was found. It starts with a desired focus position of 15. This is where the target is placed. Change this number to view different results. The $ITER R of C range should be made to cover the new Target position. Another method for changing polynomial coefficients using ALTER in a $ITER, may be found in ITER_GENERAL_First_Form.inr

script.name: ITER_OPTICAL_Second_Form.inr
script.title: Modifying OPTICAL RC with $ITER
script.description: The following uses the second form of $ITER to find the best Radius of Curvature of an OPTICAL surface to focus rays at a specified target position. The OPTICAL is actually rebuilt with a new R of C value at each iteration (the object's associated OPTICAL entity is redefined) and the XZ deviations of the the rays at the target are tested for minimum. When a best minimum is found, the new R of C is printed along with the Centroid Y position, which should equal the Target Y position. It starts with a desired focus position of 18. This is where the target is placed. Change this number to view different results. The $ITER R of C range should be made to cover the new Target position.

script.name: Iter_Over_Range.inr
script.title: Media Index based on Temperature & Pressure
script.description: The following uses the first form of $ITER to create a two-dimensional display file that relates temperature and pressure to reflectivity of a surface with a complicated index of refraction.

script.name: Iter_Root_Find01.inr
script.title: Finding Root of Equation with $ITER
script.description: Uses root finding method of $ITER.

script.name: Iter_Root_Find02.inr
script.title: Both Forms of $ITER
script.description: The following is used to locate a coordinate position along an axis that corresponds to a particular flux value. The $ITER will look for a minimum "MERIT" value starting at some initial "YSEARCH" value (in this case 10).

script.name: ITER_Singlet01.inr
script.title: $ITER for bending, first form
script.description: Optimize singlet bending with the first form of $ITER. This is the simpler form of $ITER. It only does a grid search to find the minimum value of the specified function within a user-specified range. The function minimized here is the RMS blur diameter as a function of bending. See also "ITER_SINGLET02.INR" for comparison with the second form of $ITER, and "OPTIMIZE_SINGLET.INR" for a comparison using MINIMIZE for conic sequences.

script.name: ITER_Singlet02.INR
script.title: $ITER for bending, second form
script.description: Optimize singlet bending with the second form of $ITER. This form uses singular value decomposition (SVD) to seek the minimum of a function. The function minimized here is the RMS blur diameter, as reported by the FOCUS command, as a function of bending. See also "ITER_SINGLET01.INR" for comparison with $ITER as a grid search (form 1), and "OPTIMIZE_SINGLET.INR" f or a comparison using MINIMIZE for conic sequences.

script.name: Iter_TIR_Graph.inr
script.title: Graphing Reflected Flux Approaching TIR
script.description: Uses first form of $ITER to graph a ray traced within glass at an angle range from 0 to 50Â°. The reflected flux is saved to the ITER display file and graphed at the end.

script.name: lambertian01.inr
script.title: Lambertian Scatter Towards an Edge
script.description: Demonstration of scatter towards an edge. An emitting grid is used to show Lambertian scatter through a lens toward a rectangular edge.

script.name: Laser_Coupling.inr
script.title: Laser Coupling
script.description: This file demonstrates the use of ASAP for calculating the coupling efficiency of a laser diode to a single-mode fiber. The beams must be decomposed in direction first to determine the total energy losses for the coupling efficiency calculation later.

script.name: Laser_Diode.inr
script.title: Diode Laser using DECOMPOSE DIRECTION
script.description: A model for a diode laser where DECOMPOSE DIRECTION is needed for a single narrow beam. A DECOMPOSE POSITION would not work for this case.

script.name: LCD_Diffuser_Dots.inr
script.title: LCD Edge-lit Diffuser
script.description: The following example is an LCD backlight diffuser panel using arrays of dots, having a white paint scattering property. The dots are just above the bottom surface inside the diffuser panel. The majority of flux should be reflected or scattered out of the top of the panel. This is an early example to show how to use the ARRAY command to generate separate squares of dots. Variable dot spacing may also be accomplished through the EXP option, as well as RANdom dot sizes. See Help for details. There may be a mathematical formula to create a large number of squares with varying dot size within a $DO loop if required. In this example, specific squares were generated with a fixed dot size. The light source was put along the top edge of the panel and the window for analysis was looking straight down on top of the panel. This could be modified for any configuration.

script.name: lenses01.inr
script.title: Multiple Lens Methods
script.description: Three different ways to enter the same afocal telescope with an afocal magnification of 5 1/3.

script.name: LENSES_PERFECT01.inr
script.title: PERFECT Lens with Image at Infinity
script.description: A PERFECT lens with object at 0, and image at infinity. This maintains an infinite conjugate which is essential when using PERFECT. Coherent beams are used to show that the wavefront curvature is maintained, rather than if using IDEAL.

script.name: LENSES_PERFECT02.inr
script.title: PERFECT Lens with Object at Infinity
script.description: A PERFECT lens with object at infinity. A PERFECT lens must have an infinite conjugate. This case demonstrates light focused from an infinite object. When using coherent beams, better results are achieved with PERFECT than with IDEAL, since the spherical wavefront is maintained.

script.name: LENSES_PERFECT03.inr
script.title: PERFECT Lens with Bi-directional Light Path
script.description: A PERFECT lens with a reflector at the focal plane. Shows the use of a bi-directional light path. A PERFECT lens must be used with infinite conjugates. Either the image is at infinity or the object is at infinity. Here, both paths are demostrated by the use of a mirror at one focal distance away from the lens.

script.name: Lens_Afocal.inr
script.title: An Afocal Lens
script.description: Making an afocal lens for use in 7x35 binoculars. From the Lenses chapter.

script.name: lens_array01.inr
script.title: A Discrete Lens Array
script.description: A micro-lens array with discrete lens objects using nested macro/do loops. This is better performed with bounding and using the ARRAY command.

script.name: Lens_Aspheric01.inr
script.title: Aspheric Lens by Sag Coefficients
script.description: An Aspheric lens from Melles-Griot created by USERSAG, with raytrace. This method may be used for lenses defined by sag coefficients rather than aspheric coefficients.

script.name: Lens_Box.inr
script.title: Lens Box to View Radiant Source
script.description: Lens box for viewing a Radiant Imaging source. Needs to be larger than the source dimensions. Included here for convenience.

script.name: Lens_DOME01.inr
script.title: Dome Lens
script.description: How to model a DOME lens, showing raytrace and analysis.

script.name: Lens_Doublet.inr
script.title: A Doublet Lens
script.description: How to make a doublet lens. From the Lenses chapter.

script.name: Lens_Explode_Minus.inr
script.title: Cooke Triplet with SEQUENCE and EXPLODE-
script.description: Making a 50 MM Cooke Triplet using the short form of the SEQUENCE command, combined with EXPLODE -. EXPLODE breaks up the sequence into separate surface objects. From the Lenses chapter.

script.name: Lens_Explode_Plus.inr
script.title: Cooke Triplet with SEQUENCE and EXPLODE+
script.description: Making a 50 MM Cooke Triplet using the short form of the SEQUENCE command, combined with EXPLODE +. EXPLODE breaks up the sequence into separate surface objects. From the Lenses chapter.

script.name: lens_ideal01.inr
script.title: Simple Ideal Lens
script.description: Defines an ideal lens with a focal length of 5 and whose vertex is located at z = 4. The lens is 2 in diameter.

script.name: lens_ideal02.inr
script.title: Ideal Telescope Lens
script.description: Defines an ideal afocal telescope whose first surface is located at y = -4. The diameters of the two elements are 1 and .6 and they are separated by 2. The afocal magnification of the system is 2.

script.name: lens_ideal03.inr
script.title: Ideal Lens with Raytrace
script.description: An ideal lens with a single ray traced through.

script.name: lens_ideal04.inr
script.title: Binoculars using Ideal Lenses
script.description: Make a 7X35 binoculars using ideal lenses.

script.name: Lens_Image01.inr
script.title: Landscape Lens using IMAGE
script.description: Using the IMAGE command to image rays through a lens and a pupil. It is used as a source modifier.

script.name: Lens_Image02.inr
script.title: A Lens Grid
script.description: An efficient meridional raytrace through a finite conjugate system. The stop of the lens is located close to the middle of the lens. From the Lenses chapter.

script.name: Lens_Image03.inr
script.title: IMAGE as a Lens & Edge Modifier
script.description: Using IMAGE as a LENS and an EDGE modifier.

script.name: Lens_Image04.inr
script.title: IMAGE Command used as Source modifier
script.description: Uses IMAGE as a source modifier. The modified source, placed at the image position, is compared to the original in the final plot.

script.name: lens_interface.inr
script.title: Lens Interfaces
script.description: A singlet lens and a prism lens made from different materials. See explanations below.

script.name: lens_mangin01.inr
script.title: Mangin Mirror by Curvature
script.description: A mangin mirror, using CV entries for curvature, with ray trace.

script.name: lens_mangin02.inr
script.title: Mangin Mirror by Focal Length
script.description: A mangin mirror, using FL entries for focal length and bending, with ray trace.

script.name: lens_mangin03.inr
script.title: Mangin Mirror by Radii
script.description: A mangin mirror, using RD entries for radii of curvature, with ray trace.

script.name: lens_mangin04.inr
script.title: Mangin Mirror FL in Detail
script.description: Defines a Mangin mirror whose first conicoid vertex is located at y=32. The central thickness is .75 and the aperture semi-diameter is 1.5. The focal length is 3 and the bending parameter is -1, and so the first surface is flat. Medium 1 is bounded by the two conicoids.

script.name: lens_mangin05.inr
script.title: Mangin Mirror RD
script.description: A Mangin mirror lens using RD with an absorptive interface.

script.name: lens_mangin06.inr
script.title: Mangin Mirror with Trace
script.description: A MANGIN mirror lens with an emitting rectangle to show simple use and properties.

script.name: Lens_Mirror.inr
script.title: A Lens Mirror
script.description: An example of the LENS MIRROR command. A simple parabolic concave mirror pointed towards -Z. Under the universal design law that light travels only from left to right, the focal length of a concave mirror is positive while the focal length of a convex mirror is negative. From the Lenses chapter.

script.name: lens_mirror01.inr
script.title: Parabolic Mirror Lens
script.description: A simple parabolic mirror using the LENSES command.

script.name: lens_mirror02.inr
script.title: Parabolic Mirror with Hole
script.description: Defines a parabolic mirror located at z=-15 with a semi-diameter of 5. The focal length of the mirror is 20. The central 25 percent of the mirror aperture is cut out.

script.name: lens_mirror03.inr
script.title: Cassegrain Telescope #2
script.description: Simple Cassegrain telescope using the LENSES command to make the mirrors and detector.

script.name: lens_penta01.inr
script.title: Penta-Prism Lens
script.description: PENTA makes a 90Â° deviation penta-prism with 4 circular surfaces. PLOT FACETS are needed to see the surfaces.

script.name: Lens_Penta_Prism.inr
script.title: Penta Prism Lens
script.description: An example of a penta prism lens using the PENTA command modifier. From the Lenses chapter.

script.name: Lens_Progressive_01.inr
script.title: Four Zone Progressive Optometric Lens
script.description: A four-zone optometric lens made by exploded convex-plano or concave-plano singlets using the FL (Focal Length) option and bounding. Power of zones 1 - 4 add to Zone 0 power controlled by curvature and index. Connected points compose the zonal outlines. Cross-hatched profiles are overlain on faceting to show the points grid. This lens can be used with AHEM if lines are commented out as noted below.

script.name: lens_right01.inr
script.title: Right-Angle Prism Lens
script.description: A right-angle prism made with LENSES command. The first conicoid is located at z = 0. The prism has an aperture semi-diameter of .5 and is composed of medium 1. The prism is oriented so that a ray entering the prism along the z-axis leaves the prism propagating along the positive y-direction.

script.name: lens_sequence01.inr
script.title: Simple Lens Sequence
script.description: Defines four spherical lenses whose vertices are located at (0,0,0), ( 0,0,1.25), (0,0,1.75) and (0,0,3) and are aligned with the global z axis. All lenses are 3 in semi-diameter. The respective radii of curvature are 10, -10, 40 and -20. The first two conicoids and the last two conicoids bound medium 1; the second and third conicoids bound medium 2.

script.name: lens_sequence02.inr
script.title: Lens Sequence with Media
script.description: A lens sequence using the media 'm' parameter.

script.name: lens_sequence03.inr
script.title: Lens Sequence Long Format
script.description: The prescription of this lens is the same as in a Sequence Lens. Note the first line of numerical data is entered in the long format.

script.name: Lens_Sequence_Long.inr
script.title: Long Form of SEQUENCE
script.description: A 50 MM Cooke triplet with a folding mirror that uses the long form of the SEQUENCE command. This command creates a sequence of conicoids. It can be used in its short or long form. The long form specifies the global coordinates and the normal vector of the vertex of each conicoid. In any case, the first conicoid of a SEQUENCE must be entered in the long format. From the Lenses chapter.

script.name: Lens_Sequence_Short01.inr
script.title: A Cooke Triplet using Short Form of SEQUENCE Command
script.description: A 50 MM Cooke triplet using the long form of the SEQUENCE command. This command creates a sequence of conicoids. It can be used in its short or long form. The short form uses a more compact notation and assumes that all conicoids share a similar vertex normal vector. Distances between conicoids are used to relate each conicoid. However, the first conicoid of a SEQUENCE must be entered in the long format. This example is especially designed to please lens designers that are conditioned to recognize an input sequence that ends each line with a thickness input. From the Lenses chapter.

script.name: lens_singlet01.inr
script.title: Singlet Lens by Curvature
script.description: A Singlet lens using the curvature 'CV' parameters c and c'.

script.name: lens_singlet02.inr
script.title: Singlet Lens by Focal Length
script.description: A Singlet lens using the focal length 'FL' parameters f and b.

script.name: lens_singlet03.inr
script.title: Singlet Lens by RD
script.description: A Singlet lens using radius of curvature 'RD' parameters r and r'. Defines a singlet whose front conicoid vertex is located at x = -4. The thickness is .75 and the aperture semi-diameter is 2.5. The power of the element is specified by the lens radii, which are 10 and -20 respectively. The lens is composed of medium 1.

script.name: Lens_Telescope_Chretien.inr
script.title: Ritchey-Chretien Cassegrain Telescope
script.description: A telescope using two mirrors in a Ritchey-Chretien Cassegrain configuration. The TELESCOPE command is programmed to design telescopes that are always corrected for third order spherical aberration. The radii of curvature of the primary and secondary mirrors are respectively 400 and 140 mm. The primary mirror obscuration is created automatically. Aberration control is done via the addition of conics on the two mirrors that eliminates third order spherical aberration and coma. This results in a Ritchey-ChrÃ©tien telescope design that is limited by astigmatism. From the Lenses chapter.

script.name: Lens_Telescope_Maksutov.inr
script.title: Maksutov-Cassegrain Telescope
script.description: A two mirror telescope design similar to a Maksutov-Cassegrain, using the LENS TELESCOPE command. The reference point of the system is the vertex of the primary mirror and it is oriented and located given the defined global coordinates axis and location. The second mirror of the Cassegrain configuration has a negative power and a positive magnification. This is an example of the design with two concentric mirrors with the stop. Such location of the mirrors eliminates third order coma, astigmatism and distortion without the addition of conics on the mirror. However, ASAP is programmed to always eliminate spherical aberration. That is why the two mirrors end up with conic constants that correct spherical aberration and coma. From the Lenses chapter.

script.name: Lens_Telescope_Parabolic.inr
script.title: Parabolic Telescope
script.description: A one mirror telescope using a simple parabolic mirror. The TELESCOPE command is programmed to design telescopes that are always corrected for third order spherical aberration. The one mirror telescope has a 40 mm radius of curvature (2xFL). The mirror conic constant is automatically set to -1 for a parabola that corrects spherical aberration. From the Lenses chapter.

script.name: Lens_Telescope_Schmidt.inr
script.title: Schmidt Telescope with Corrector
script.description: A one mirror telescope using a simple parabolic mirror. The TELESCOPE command is programmed to design telescopes that are always corrected for third order spherical aberration. The mirror has a 40 mm radius of curvature (2xFL). In this design, the mirror is concentric with the stop (the corrector plate). Such configuration eliminates third order coma, astigmatism and distortion introduced by the mirror. The asphericity of the corrector plate corrects spherical aberration and the mirror remains spherical with a zero conic constant. From the Lenses chapter.

script.name: Lens_Triplet_Composite.inr
script.title: Triplet Lens using REPEAT and COMPOSITE
script.description: A lens triplet using the REPEAT and COMPOSITE commands. The COMPOSITE command combines several lens entities into a single lens entity. IDEAL lens entities are not allowed in a composite set. The REPEAT command repeats previously defined entity data that may subsequently be changed by linear transformations. From the Lenses chapter.

script.name: lens_wedge01.inr
script.title: Glass Wedge Lens
script.description: A wedge of glass made with LENSES command.

script.name: library02.inr
script.title: Macro Input Records
script.description: Shows the proper way to call macros with input records.

script.name: limits01.inr
script.title: Object Bounding Box
script.description: Defines an optical surface with a radius of curvature equal to -30 and a conic constant equal to -1. The object is bounded by a cylinder whose semi-diameter is equal to 4 and whose z limits [in global coordinates] extend from -1 to 1. The object has a hole with a semi-diameter of .8 at its origin.

script.name: line01.inr
script.title: A Line Edge
script.description: A straight line edge.

script.name: Line_Source.inr
script.title: Grid Converging to a Line
script.description: Demostrates the creation of a grid source which focuses to a line. The +\- x-coordinates are made large to force the ellipsoid focii to form a line.

script.name: list01.inr
script.title: LIST Command Options
script.description: Various options of the LIST command. See below for explanations.

script.name: list02.inr
script.title: List Command Output
script.description: Output examples of various LIST command options.

script.name: list03.inr
script.title: Output of LISTing Parabasals
script.description: Using LIST for outputing parabasal ray data. Example shows PS, DS, P#, and D# options.

script.name: list_ellipse.inr
script.title: LIST ELLIPSE Output
script.description: The LIST ELLIPSE command output for "POLARIZ X 0 1" on a grid of rays in the Z direction.

script.name: LIST_INTEGER.inr
script.title: LIST INTEGER output
script.description: Demonstration of LIST INTEGER. Some simple geometry is created, a trace is performed and the result of the command LIST INTEGER is shown.

script.name: LIST_RAYS.inr
script.title: LIST RAYS output
script.description: Demonstration of LIST RAYS. Some simple geometry is created, a trace is performed and the result of the command LIST RAYS is shown.

script.name: Literal_Passing01.inr
script.title: Passing Literals to a Macro
script.description: The do's and don't's of passing numerical values as a literal to a macro,

script.name: Literal_Passing02.inr
script.title: Passing Variables to Plot Titles
script.description: Passing variables to plot titles using the LIT operator and a macro.

script.name: lsqfit01.inr
script.title: Least Squares Fit Control
script.description: Using LSQFIT to modify the singular value decomposition method used by the REVOLUTION command's least squares fitting algorythm. Note the use of $FCN to create the data for REVOLUTION. If the fits are not good then consider breaking the OBJECT into many piecewise OBJECTS for fits over smaller divisions.

script.name: lsqfit02.inr
script.title: LSQFIT Output
script.description: Example output from LSQFIT command.

script.name: Lyot_Filter01.inr
script.title: Illustration of a three-stage Lyot filter
script.description: This model uses three cascaded stages that are first, second, and fourth order, respectively. Each stage consists of a polarizer/analyzer and a crystal waveplate that modulates the throughput of the stage (as a function of wavelength, angle, ...). Each waveplate is rotated about the device axis 45 degrees relative to the X polarizer/analyzers so it may act on the two polarization components and rotate the resultant polarization. This results in modulation of throughput at the following analyzer. A diverging point grid source with X nominal polarization illuminates the filter. All polarizers are X-aligned. The throughput is checked using field energy integral at the detector. The position of all geometry elements is set by variables to make it simple to keep these (typically) thin elements from colliding. The element size and the detector size is scaled to be sure to capture the entire beam. This model uses quartz refractive index data at 400, 458, 590, and 694 nm from J.V.Atansoff and P.J.Hart, Phys. Rev. Vol.59, pp 85-96 1941, and A.W.Lawson, Phys. Rev. Vol 59, pp.838-839, 1941 Wavelengths from 351 to 980 nm are included, so a reference wavelength should be set within this range to avoid extrapolation.

script.name: Mach-Zehnder_Interferometer_01.inr
script.title: Mach-Zehnder Interferometer
script.description: Mach-Zehnder interferometer with circular fringes resulting from point-source illumination with a dense-medium slab to change the optical path length in one arm. Derived from Michelson_Interferometer.inr example.

script.name: macro_$args01.inr
script.title: Macro Argument Passing
script.description: Two examples of using $ARGS with a user-defined macro.

script.name: macro_$args02.inr
script.title: $ARGS to Call Dialog Box
script.description: Using $ARGS to create a dialog box for passing arguments to a macro.

script.name: Macro_$ARGS03.inr
script.title: The USER Option
script.description: The USER option tells ASAP what to do with unspecified arguments in the "calling" line to the macro. It allows arguments to be left off that are not specifically prompted for in the macro. Normally, if arguments are left off, ASAP will prompt the user, even if there are no prompts supplied by the macro. This allows for easier batch mode operation. Note that for all macros, the #n's are simple text substitutions done before any parsing occurs on the macro lines themselves. Any arguments that are left off are substituted with blanks.

script.name: Macro_$ASK01.inr
script.title: $ASK Predefined Macro
script.description: Demonstrates the use of $ASK.

script.name: macro_$ask02.inr
script.title: $ASK Pausing and Prompting
script.description: Demonstrates the use of $ASK for pausing a script and prompting for input. Also shows A $DO loop containing a $IF...THEN structure using $NEXT to jump to top of loop and $LEAVE to prematurely exit loop.

script.name: macro_$datim01.inr
script.title: Turn off Plotting Date and Time
script.description: How to turn off Date and Time stamps from showing up in plots. This may be desired when wanting to copy plots for publication purposes. A handy command to store into a User-defined button.

script.name: macro_$dbg01.inr
script.title: Output of $DBG Macro
script.description: Example output of $DBG showing how ASAP parser reads an input line. Used for debugging purposes. In the second part, since the command is on the same line, it does not get sent to the kernal.

script.name: Macro_$DO01.inr
script.title: $DO Predefined Macro
script.description: Simple $DO loop to create 3 planes.

script.name: Macro_$DO02.inr
script.title: Arrays with $DO & Macros
script.description: Making an array by calling a macro containing a $DO loop from another $DO loop. In this case, the other $DO loop is in a second macro which calls a third macro to create the geometry. See explanations in the body below.

script.name: macro_$edit01.inr
script.title: Example Output of $EDIT
script.description: Example output of $EDIT showing the default response when no options are given. Otherwise, the filename, macro or string may be specified on the command line.

script.name: macro_$err01.inr
script.title: Branching on Input Error
script.description: Example of $ERR usage. Error flag is set with $ERR command. At any time after this command is issued, ASAP will branch down to the bottom label if it encounters an input error and will resume executing with the RAYS 0 command.

script.name: Macro_$EVAL01.inr
script.title: Graphing a Function with $EVAL
script.description: Evaluating a simple sine-wave function in X using $EVAL. Uses the first form, where a range and steps are given for the variable. Produces the display file eval.dis which can be graphed.

script.name: Macro_$FCN01.inr
script.title: $FCN Predefined Macro
script.description: Simple use of $FCN. A hyperbolic sine function is defined and named SINH which accepts a single parameter using the underscore character (_).

script.name: Macro_$GO01.inr
script.title: $GO Predefined Macro
script.description: Skipping a portion of code using the $GO pre-defined macro. The label used here may be lower or upper case. Lower case was chosen to allow easy commenting out of $GO line, without having to find the closing label (lower case ignored otherwise).

script.name: macro_$go02.inr
script.title: Jump and Skip with $GO
script.description: Using $GO to skip records or jump to other locations in the program. Several examples are shown below. Note that the jump-to label must begin in the first column.

script.name: Macro_$GRAB01.inr
script.title: $GRAB Predefined Macro
script.description: Demonstrates the use of $GRAB. Uses $GRAB to assign variables to numbers that are printed to the command console.

script.name: Macro_$GRAB02.inr
script.title: Grabbing Console Output
script.description: Using $GRAB to grab console output data and assign to variables, for saving, printing or using in calculations. The example below grabs data from a STATS POS output (looks for the 1st three numbers after the string "Centroid") to set up a WINDOW command.

script.name: Macro_$HELP01.inr
script.title: Using $HELP
script.description: Several examples of using $HELP. Note when "&" is used instead of "$" it only shows the command format without text description.

script.name: Macro_$IF01.inr
script.title: $IF Predefined Macro #1
script.description: Demonstrates the use of $IF.

script.name: Macro_$IF02.inr
script.title: $IF Predefined Macro #2
script.description: Using $IF to provide typical decision branching found in most programming environments. $IF's may be nested.

script.name: Macro_$IF03.inr
script.title: Examples with $IF THEN
script.description: Several examples of using $IF.

script.name: Macro_$IO01.inr
script.title: $IO Predefined Macro #1
script.description: Simple use of $IO to output data to a file. FILE(10) tells ASAP to use a file unit number of 10 or higher.

script.name: Macro_$IO02.inr
script.title: $IO for Redirection
script.description: Using $IO to output selected data to a file. Shows hot to turn off console output while writing to file. Also shows how to append data to the current file. FILE(10) tells ASAP to use a file unit number of 10 or higher.

script.name: Macro_$IO03.inr
script.title: $IO for Program Breaks
script.description: Using $IO to provide a break or pause in a script file. Here, after geometry is created, a $IO pauses execution. another $IO typed from the command console allows the program to continue from that point. If not, you must hit the END button to start again.

script.name: Macro_$IO04.inr
script.title: File Input and IO Control
script.description: Several examples of using $IO.

script.name: Macro_$ITER01.inr
script.title: $ITER Predefined Macro
script.description: Using $ITER to plot a function over a specified range (including end points). The result for Y is found over 40 points taken in the X range of

script.name: macro_$iter02.inr
script.title: Iterating Records
script.description: Plotting transverse ray abberations using $ITER. The $ITER below looks for a ray with minimum Y value over a range of rows that were printed to the output console.

script.name: Macro_$ITER03.inr
script.title: $ITER Root Find Output
script.description: Output produced from $ITER root finding example. This is not a runable inr file.

script.name: macro_$leave01.inr
script.title: Example of $LEAVE
script.description: Example of where to use $LEAVE. In this case, if $IF is true, it will leave the $DO loop.

script.name: Macro_$REG01.inr
script.title: Example of $REG
script.description: Various ways of using $REG to print out variable or register values. Note that "&" in place of "$" makes for a cleaner output.

script.name: Macro_$SCR01.inr
script.title: $SCR and Cancel
script.description: A few examples of using $SCR to print out a dialog box of information and how to test for and use the Cancel button.

script.name: Macro_$SCR02.inr
script.title: Screen Entry with $SCR
script.description: Using $SCR to generate an input screen for the user. Suppose you wanted to setup a screen entry for a mirror. One possibility involving two macros is shown below. The second macro MAKEOBJ was necessary in order to get the name of the OBJECT contained in the N" variable into the comment string. If you had written OBJECT 'N"' instead, the parser would have put the character string N" into the comment rather than the contents of N".

script.name: Macro_$SCR03.inr
script.title: Output Formatting with $SCR
script.description: Using $SCR to generate output of text and values in a desired format. While the $REG command is useful for printing out variable information, it is crude because it doesn't allow formatting. The $SCR command is a convenient way to output data in a more aesthetic manner. Consider the following simplistic comparison of printing the contents of two variables.

script.name: Macro_$STO_RCL01.inr
script.title: Saving and Retrieving Stored Variables
script.description: How to save and retrieve variables from saved register files. See below for examples. This is not a runable inr file.

script.name: Macro_$SYS01.inr
script.title: $SYS to Run External Commands
script.description: Shows how $SYS may be used to perform an external process. In this case, temp files are created by the PICTURE command and may be left behind. $SYS is used to delete the unwanted files when done. The screen will go black while executing the command prompt function.

script.name: Macro_$SYS02.inr
script.title: Passing Literals to $SYS Macro
script.description: Shows how a $SYS may be performed via macro to enable passing to it a concatenated string that controls an external process. The result of this $SYS is simply to delete the unwanted files when the script ends.

script.name: Macro_$TIC01.inr
script.title: Time Interval Check using $TIC
script.description: Using $TIC to measure elapsed time. An interval of CPU time is tracked from one TIC to the next. The &TIC is used to reset the timer with no elapsed time output generated. Optional fixed time units may be specified (MICroseconds, MILiseconds, SEConds, MINutes, HOUrs, YEArs, or OFF for floating units).

script.name: macro_$view01.inr
script.title: 3D View of Geometry
script.description: Displaying a 3D view of geometry in the 3D viewer. A model of a Petzval lens.

script.name: Macro_Fresnel_Lens.inr
script.title: Fresnel Lens Macro
script.description: A macro that makes an aspheric Fresnel lens. It uses parameters based on Edmund Scientic Fresnel lens. Another smaller macro is used for creating a test source.

script.name: macro_library.inr
script.title: Example Library of Macros
script.description: This is an example set of macros to be saved as a library file with the .LIB extension.

script.name: Macro_User01.inr
script.title: A Simple Macro
script.description: The basic user-defined macro. Makes a spherical mirror.

script.name: map_slopes.inr
script.title: Accessing Multivalued Display Files
script.description: Using DISPLAY options of 1ST, 2ND, and so forth, to access additional matrix values. Some display commands will produce these additional matrices. For this example, MAP SLOPES is used. It creates two additional matrices of slope values for each window dimension. These are accessed through the 2ND and 3RD option as shown below.

script.name: matrix01.inr
script.title: MATRIX Rotation
script.description: Example of a MATRIX command equivalent to a ROTATE.

script.name: matrix02.inr
script.title: MATRIX PREVIOUS Option
script.description: Example of a MATRIX command

script.name: matrix03.inr
script.title: Compare MATRIX and ROTATE
script.description: Compare the MATRIX command to the ROTATE command. Create 1 Plane surface. Then create 2 identical surfaces at the same place. ROTATE 1 of the surfaces. Use the MATRIX command to rotate the other surface. Inspect with 3D-Viewer.

script.name: MATRIX04.inr
script.title: Converting MATRIX to Discrete Translations
script.description: Convert a direct MATRIX command input to a discrete sequence of ROTATEs and SHIFTs using the LIST option. Create 1 Plane surface with MATRIX. Apply the LIST option at the end of the last line. This gives the rotational angle info to use with ROTATE in the Ouput Console. Can use either X-Y-Z or Z-Y-X data to reconstruct the translation matrix (not both) using discrete ROTATE commands. Note that Z-Y-X is in that order even though it falls under the columns in the order of X-Y-Z. ROTATE commands must be referenced to Global Origin, and therefore any additional SHIFTs must follow at the end. SHIFTs are determined by the number in the first column (displacement vector). In this example, only a Z shift is given. A second surface is created with the discrete commands and is compared to the other, showing they overlap exactly. A LIST is also done after the last translation command, in this case SHIFT, to show the computed MATRIX is the same as the previous MATRIX entered. The first line in the Matrix output can be ignored. Initially, for this example, simple integer numbers were used with ROTATE and SHIFT and the LIST output was copied and used for the direct MATRIX input on the first surface. This shows the LIST output may be used either way for conversion.

script.name: MATRIX05.inr
script.title: MATRIX For Source Coordinate System Conversion
script.description: Example of using the MATRIX command to change from left handed to right handed coordinate system. This can be useful for converting Radiant Imaging ray files to the ASAP right-handed system.

script.name: MATRIX06.inr
script.title: MATRIX 'k' Option
script.description: Example of using the MATRIX k option to specify a previous entities' matrix.

script.name: media01.inr
script.title: Defining Non-dispersive Media
script.description: Defining non-dispersive media. Three examples of using the MEDIA command are given.

script.name: media02.inr
script.title: Defining Dispersive Media
script.description: Defining wavelengths and their associated dispersive media.

script.name: Media_Absorb.inr
script.title: Making Absorbing Media
script.description: How to make an absorbing media letting ASAP calculate the absorption, using MEDIA ABSORB command.

script.name: MEDIA_ABSORB02.inr
script.title: Making Absorbing Media #2
script.description: Using the absorption coefficient on the MEDIA command line. Origin is at Vertex 1. Propagation direction is +Z. Units are in MM.

script.name: MESH_COLOR01.inr
script.title: MESH Plot Using COLOR Option
script.description: How to do a mesh plot of multiple sources in different colors. Two sources are created to emit in opposite directions. A radiant distribution of each source is averaged around the X-Y plane. A MESH plot with assigned color is sent to the vector file which can be displayed in the 3-D viewer. The default for MESH is B&W.

script.name: mesh_object.inr
script.title: Mesh Object from Edges
script.description: A mesh object formed from edges.

script.name: michelson_interferometer.inr
script.title: Michelson Interferometer
script.description: Interferometer using two mirrors and a beam splitter. A plane wave splits in two, hits two mirrors at equal distance and are sent back through the splitter to end up at the same location on the detector. One mirror is tilted slightly to show the interference effects between the two beams.

script.name: mie_scatter_mil1246c.inr
script.title: MIL-STD 1246C Particle Scatter
script.description: Mie scatter calculation for bsdf of a surface with MIL-STD 1246C contamination distribution. Change wavelength and index of refraction for the particles matching your system. Also must set the coverage fraction and cleanliness level. They are not independent. If you know your cleanliness level, then the coverage fraction has a corresponding value. Particle model works well with large wavelengths or where particle size is small compared to wavelength. If particles get large compared to wavelength, then BSDF may not be correct for angles less than 2 or 3 degrees.

script.name: missed01.inr
script.title: Rays Missing Absorbing Surface
script.description: Shows ho to display missed rays in the 3D viewer. Note that 2D plots show missed rays out to edge of plot as a convenience, but will not normally show up in 3D viewer. Uses an emitting spheroid reflected off an extruded edge toward an absorbing plane.

script.name: modify.inr
script.title: MODIFY Display Command
script.description: Modifies the distribution. Performed after a DISPLAY command.

script.name: move01.inr
script.title: Moving Rays along Trajectory
script.description: Model of a landscape lens to demonstrate MOVE command. Entrance pupil is located 5.639 inches from 1st surface. Entrance pupil is 1 inch in diameter and 10 degrees off-axis. Before and after SPOTS are shown.

script.name: MOVE_TO_PLANE.inr
script.title: Moving a Source to a Plane
script.description: Demonstration of MOVE TO PLANE. Some simple geometry is created and the source is moved to a different location (plane).

script.name: MOVE_TO_POINT.INR
script.title: Moving a Source to a Point
script.description: Demonstration of MOVE TO POINT. Some simple geometry is created and the source is moved to a different location (point).

script.name: MOVE_TO_SPHERE.inr
script.title: Moving a source to a reference sphere
script.description: Demonstration of MOVE TO SPHERE. Some simple geometry is created and a source is moved to a different location along a reference sphere.

script.name: Msquared.inr
script.title: Creating and characterizing an M-squared gaussian beam in ASAP
script.description: Demonstrates technique for creating an M-squared laser beam in ASAP. Requires making a wavelength adjustment to compensate for the increased divergence of a non-ideal gaussian.

script.name: mtf_ideal_lens.inr
script.title: MTF from an Ideal Lens
script.description: MTF produced by an ideal lens using FFT. First the PSF is plotted at one wavelength. Then the spatial frequency spectrum is calculated with FFT and plotted.

script.name: mtf_obscured.inr
script.title: Monochromatic Diffraction MTF
script.description: Monochromatic diffraction MTF of an obscured aperture F/2 system.

script.name: Multiple_Display_Graph_01.inr
script.title: Multiple 1D Display Files in One 2D Graph
script.description: Demonstrates the combining 1-dimensional graphs into a single 2-dimensional distribution so the graphs are easily ploted together. A Gaussian superposition of beams is illustrated as an example.

script.name: multiple_iter_graph.inr
script.title: Graphing Multiple ITER Results
script.description: Graphing several iter display files on one plot. A $ITER which performs wavelength vs. irradiance over a thermal spectrum is put inside a macro. This way the iter may be called from a $DO loop, passing it a parameter which changes the absorption of the material. On each loop a $ITER display file is produced and plotted on the same graph. Probably an unnecessarily complicated way to show how to graph several display files in the same plot after having fixed the range.

script.name: multi_color_source01.inr
script.title: Multi-color Source
script.description: Using an emitting object at multiple specified by SPECTRUM VISIBLE.

script.name: numbers_names.inr
script.title: NUMBERS NAMES Output
script.description: Output from the NUMBERS NAMES command.

script.name: object01.inr
script.title: A Single Edge Object
script.description: An example of a single EDGE object.

script.name: object02.inr
script.title: Slicing Irradiance with SPREAD
script.description: Solid object formed from a collection of surfaces. This uses the second form of the OBJECT command.

script.name: OBJECT_Redefine01.inr
script.title: Redefining OBJECT Properties
script.description: How to change the properties of a previously-defined object. In this case, the interface properties are changed.

script.name: OBJECT_Redefine02.inr
script.title: Redefining Objects: A Practical Application
script.description: An application for modifying SURFACE and OBJECT database settings, including BOUNDS. This example shows a TUBE filled part way with water that rises a certain amount through each pass of the loop. INTERFACE COATING assignments are properly maintained for all objects by updating on each pass. Source creation, ray tracing, and analysis would normally be included withing the loop, as well. A RAYS 0 should be performed at the top of the loop to clear previously traced rays. All other objects, including detector can be made before the loop, similar to the TUBE_OUTER seen here.

script.name: Object_Tree_Branching.inr
script.title: Making an Object Tree
script.description: The following demonstrates the use of the BRANCH command to assign common names to a group of objects that have a common theme. The individual objects of the branch are sequentially numbered using a $DO loop. The branch name is given just before each common group of objects is created. New branch names may be tacked on to the last one by using a period (.) before the name. New branch names could also be attached to previous levels by using the caret (^) symbol before the name. This moves the assignment up one level (for each caret).

script.name: OCTAGONAL_PYRAMID_ARRAY_CROSSED_ROOFS.inr
script.title: Octagonal pyramid array by bounded, crossed ROOFS
script.description: An ARRAY of hexagonal pyramids is made using crossed ROOF surfaces. The three ROOFs are mutually bounded to form the pyramids. Please note the possibility for ray leakage (see Help, ROOF command) (approx 3% measured) when directing rays on axis with the pyramids. This should not be a concern when intersecting with randomized ray directions.

script.name: OFFSET01.inr
script.title: Use of the OFFSET command
script.description: Create a BRO009.DAT file with first element of Cooke Triplet and GRID source. OFFSET simply moves the distribution file to the new location without altering the shape.

script.name: opdmap01.inr
script.title: Wavefront Map of Singlet
script.description: Making an on-axis and off-axis wavefront map of a singlet lens using OPDMAP.

script.name: optical04.inr
script.title: Cassegrain Telescope #1
script.description: Simple Cassegrain telescope using the OPTICAL command to make the mirrors.

script.name: Optical_Activity.inr
script.title: Analyzing Optically Active Media
script.description: Using PLOT POLAR and LIST ELLIPSE to analyze a crystal-type polarizer coupled to an optically active element. The CRYSTAL media generates two rays, ordinary and extraordinary. The ordinary ray is then sent through the active medium where its polarization state rotates as it propagates. The polarization is plotted as it is traced in steps, in a timed loop, to allow the polarization vector direction to be watched as it evolves.

script.name: OPTICAL_Dual.inr
script.title: Dual OPTICAL Surface
script.description: Two examples of making two-sided singlet lenses as one object. The second line provides the optional second surface parameters. The first argument given is the relative distance (t) from the first surface. The first example shows an aspheric optical surface whose vertex is located at y = 0 with a radius of curvature of -30 and a conic constant of -1. The 4th, 6th, 8th and 10th order deformation coefficients are 1E-3,

script.name: Optimize01.inr
script.title: Optimizing a Cassegrain Telescope
script.description: Optimization of a telescope mirror system. Within the specified constraints, finds the minimum rms spot size on axis. The results are stored and the optimized system is traced.

script.name: Optimize01_temp.inr
script.title: Optimizing a Cassegrain Telescope
script.description: Optimization of a telescope mirror system. Within the specified constraints, finds the minimum rms spot size on axis. The results are stored and the optimized system is traced.

script.name: Optimize02.inr
script.title: Optimizing a Maksutov Telescope
script.description: Optimization of a telescope mirror system, within specified constraints. Uses a fast algorithm that finds the minimum rms spot size at a single on-axis field.

script.name: Optimize03.inr
script.title: Optimizing a Fourier Transform Lens
script.description: Optimization of a multi-element telecentric lens system. Default is 10 elements. Several field locations are used. The final result is saved as a macro and run.

script.name: Optimize04.inr
script.title: Optimizing a three-lens imaging system
script.description: An attempt at optimizing a three-lens system. The result can be compared to the "Cooke Triplet" design included in William Smith's book, "Modern Lens Design".

script.name: Optimize_Singlet.inr
script.title: Optimizing a singlet lens
script.description: Optimization of singlet lens bending factor. Finds the minimum rms spot size on axis. The results are stored and the optimized system is traced. The resulting bending factor and curvatures are printed at the end. See also "ITER_SINGLET01.INR" and "ITER_SINGLET02.INR" for a comparison using $ITER (both forms).

script.name: Optimize_Singlet_temp.inr
script.title: Optimizing a singlet lens
script.description: Optimization of singlet lens bending factor. Finds the minimum rms spot size on axis. The results are stored and the optimized system is traced. The resulting bending factor and curvatures are printed at the end. See also "ITER_SINGLET01.INR" and "ITER_SINGLET02.INR" for a comparison using $ITER (both forms).

script.name: Output_ANGLES.inr
script.title: Using VALUES to Output Exact Angle Data
script.description: Shows how to output an exact angular range of -90 to 90 to a text file. The idea is to get a slice along the X and Y with increments every 2 degrees. Normally, a distribution file has a range of -89.x to 89.x, where x is determined by the number of PIXELS. The outermost pixels can't go beyond the window edge. Using VALUES, actual data coordinates are given which extracts an interpolated value from the distribution. This allows one to produce a file that begins exactly at the ends of the window, such as -90 to 90 (or -1 to 1 in dir-cosine space). The end values would be extrapolated from the closest nearby pixel. Accuracy should improve with more rays and higher PIXELS.

script.name: Output_Formatted01.inr
script.title: Writing Formatted Output #1
script.description: Demonstrates the use of $IO to redirect data, and $SCR to write out lines of formatted output. In this example the data are written to RAYDATA.TXT. Four values are written by $SCR each time through the loop. The "1" after $SCR tells ASAP to expect one line of formatting information after the commmand (120 chars max). The width of each field is indicated by the distance between the / / delimiters. The .9 tells ASAP to write a floating- point number with nine places after the decimal point. FILE(10) tells ASAP to use a file unit number of 10 or higher.

script.name: Output_Formatted02.inr
script.title: Writing Formatted Output #2
script.description: Demonstrates the use of $IO to redirect data, and $SCR to write out lines of formatted output. In this example the data are written to a file named TEST. Three values are written each time $SCR is encountered. The "1" after $SCR tells ASAP to expect one line of formatting information after the commmand. The width of each field is indicated by the distance between the / / delimiters. The .9 tells ASAP to write a floating- point number with nine places after the decimal point. To append more data to the file TEST (in a DO loop, for example), use +FILE(21) on subsequent output redirection, as shown at the bottom.

script.name: Output_Formatted03.inr
script.title: Writing Formatted Output #3
script.description: This file shows how to grab console output and write the data to a file with formatting using $SCR.

script.name: Output_Formatted04.inr
script.title: Writing EXTREMES POSITION Data to File
script.description: Demonstration of grabbing console output of EXTREMES POSITION, slightly reformatting the data format,

script.name: Output_Formatted05.inr
script.title: Writing Variable Filename with Date stamp
script.description: This file shows how to enter an arbitrary filename to be used as an output file and put the current date in the title. It continues to append output data to a file with formatting using $SCR.

script.name: Output_Log_File.inr
script.title: Writing Out Data to Log File
script.description: A very convenient macro for writing a log file. It allows writing output in one command line.

script.name: Output_Plot_Data.inr
script.title: Writing Plot Data to a File
script.description: Shows how to output data to a text file that would normally be plotted.

script.name: Output_Sci_Not.inr
script.title: Writing Data to File in Scientific Notation
script.description: This example shows how to output numbers in scientific notation to a formatted data file using DISPLAY and TEXTFILE. A FIELD file created with variables in any format can be outputted in the same format using TEXTFILE. A $GRAB could have been used to assign these variables.

script.name: oval01.inr
script.title: An Oval Edge
script.description: A partial oval edge made with OVAL and displayed with PLOT EDGES.

script.name: overlay01.inr
script.title: OVERLAY to Combine Plots
script.description: Examples of using OVERLAY to combine plots into a single plot.

script.name: overlay02.inr
script.title: OVERLAY for Quadrant Views
script.description: Using OVERLAY for Quadrant views.

script.name: Overlay03.inr
script.title: Overlaying DIRECTIONAL UNWRAP Plots
script.description: How to overlay DIRECTIONAL UNWRAP plots using original display viewer.

script.name: Overlay04.inr
script.title: Quadrant Plot of Two Spatial Filters
script.description: Multiple overlays performed to show two spatial filters in one plot. Taken from Aperture_Sampling02.inr.

script.name: Parabolic_Strip.inr
script.title: Parabolic Strip by Swept Edge
script.description: This shows how to make a parabolic surface section using POINTS with the 2 option to specify a parabolic curve with control point. SWEEP DIRECTION makes the strip surface.

script.name: paths01.inr
script.title: Stray Light Analysis with PATHS
script.description: A simple example to show a typical use of the PATHS command for ghost image analysis. Several surfaces are set up to create multiple trace paths through splitting and scattering. Paths are listed after the trace using the PATHS command.

script.name: paths02.inr
script.title: Typical PATHS Output
script.description: Typical output from the PATHS command for all currently defined rays. This output shows the default LONG form and listing according to total flux.

script.name: penta01.inr
script.title: Penta Prism Lens
script.description: Defines a penta-angle prism whose first conicoid is located at z=0. The prism has an aperture semi-diameter of .5 and is composed of medium 1. The prism is oriented so that a ray entering the prism along the z-axis leaves the prism propagating along the positive y-direction.

script.name: Phase_Conjugate_01.inr
script.title: Creating a Phase Conjugate or Mask
script.description: Make a source of specified Hermite-Gaussian wavefront. Capture the complex field of the wavefront. Extract the real and imaginary parts of the field. Composite these together into a file that can be read in to create a mask that represents the complex-conjugate condition. Create a new unit reference field. Impose the conjugate mask on the unit field to obtain the conjugate field. THIS SCRIPT WAS CREATED IN RESPONSE TO SEVERAL ISSUES. It illustrates that we can create a complex field file from its real and imaginary parts individually, which facilitates common operations such as conjugation, phase mask construction, etc. Other uses are left as an exercise for the reader.

script.name: Photometry.inr
script.title: 'Radiometric Analysis' Appendix File
script.description: This file is from the appendix of the Radiometric Analysis (BRO0909.pdf) Tech Guide. It has not been altered from its original form, and may be used

script.name: Pinhole_Array.inr
script.title: Array of Pinholes
script.description: This shows how to create a pinhole array in a panel by bounding a plane to an array of tubes.

script.name: plane01.inr
script.title: Rectangular PLANE Surface
script.description: Defines a plane normal to the z axis at z = 5. Requires the key word SURFACE precede the command. Note also that this PLANE is not yet an OBJECT, i.e., something that may be ray traced.

script.name: plane02.inr
script.title: Elliptical PLANE Surface
script.description: A plane surface using the ELLIPSE modifier to describe its boundary.

script.name: plane03.inr
script.title: PLANE NORMAL Surface
script.description: A plane surface using the NORMAL option. This example shows a plane that contains the point 0,0,0 and whose Normal vector is 0,1,1. The LOCAL modifier is needed to define the boundaries of the surface. Note that ASAP will calculate the vector 0,1,1 as 45Â° from Z or Y.

script.name: plane04.inr
script.title: PLANE POINTS Surface
script.description: A plane surface described by three points on the surface. The Normal is determined by the right-hand rule.

script.name: plane_wave.inr
script.title: Simple Truncated Plane Wave
script.description: A simple truncated plane wave made with GRID.

script.name: plot01.inr
script.title: Plotting Beams
script.description: Plotting Gaussian beams with an overlayed spot diagram.

script.name: plot02.inr
script.title: Plotting Edges and Facets
script.description: Plotting Edges and Facets.

script.name: plot03.inr
script.title: Plotting Lenses
script.description: ASAP model of Petzval lens to demonstrate plotting.

script.name: plot04.inr
script.title: Graphical Analysis of Polarization
script.description: Plotting polarization using PLOT POLAR and PLOT RAYS.

script.name: plot3d.inr
script.title: PLOT3D Display Command
script.description: Create a 3-Dimensional plot of a SPOTS POSITION distribution file. Performed after a DISPLAY command. Does not modify display data. A Gaussian apodized grid is plotted.

script.name: Plotting_Mesh.inr
script.title: Mesh Plot Display of a Source
script.description: This shows how to do a mesh plot of a source or set of rays. Two sources are created to emit in opposite directions. A radiant distribution is made which is averaged around the X-Y plane. The mesh plot sends data to the vector file which can be displayed in the 3-D viewer or by using the DRAWING command.

script.name: PLOT_Saving1.inr
script.title: Saving MODEL...PLOT Data to File
script.description: Demonstrates writing BSDF PLOT data to a file using $IO OUTPUT. Uses a VOLUME Media as an example. Writes plot data from display "slices" of a 3D display file containing the default incident angles.

script.name: PLOT_Saving2.inr
script.title: Saving MODEL...PLOT Data to File #2
script.description: Demonstrates writing BSDF PLOT data to a file using $IO OUTPUT. Uses a VOLUME Media as an example. Writes plot data from separate display files at specific incident angles.

script.name: PLOT_Saving3.inr
script.title: Saving MODEL...PLOT Data to File #3
script.description: Demonstrates writing BSDF PLOT data to a file. Uses a VOLUME Media as an example. Writes plot data from separate display files at specific incident angles.

script.name: PLOT_Saving4.inr
script.title: Saving MODEL...PLOT Data to File #4 - with Loop
script.description: Demonstrates writing BSDF PLOT data to a file. Uses a VOLUME Media as an example. Writes plot data from display "slices" of a 3D display file containing the default incident angles. Uses $DO loop to save all files.

script.name: plot_text01.inr
script.title: Annotating Plots with Text
script.description: How to add labels to a plot using the TEXT option of the PLOT command.

script.name: plot_text02.inr
script.title: Color Chart with Labels
script.description: ASAP color chart with labeling using the TEXT option on the PLOT command. ASAP assigns the colors automatically in this sequence. Handy reference for seeing printed color results.

script.name: Plot_Text03.inr
script.title: Passing Variables to Plot Labels
script.description: Labeling a plot using numbers or strings contained in variables. The PLOT command is contained within a macro to allow passing of variables into plot labels using the TEXT option. Numeric data is passed using the LIT operator and strings are passed by using one double quote on the right side. Be sure to set the coordinate position (spacing) of labels to allow for length of variables.

script.name: points01.inr
script.title: POINTS and Weighting
script.description: Shows the effect of varying weighting factors and control vertices.

script.name: POINTS_Arc.inr
script.title: POINTS Curve using Arc Parameter
script.description: This creates a simple curve using the "-2" connection parameter. The Radius and Angle may be changed to see how the "parent ellipse" point with angular subtense works.

script.name: Point_Source_Towards_Aperture_01.inr
script.title: Simple Problem
script.description: Example of a point source entering an aperture.

script.name: polariz01.inr
script.title: Linear Vertical Polarization
script.description: Setting up the POLARIZ command for a linear, vertically polarized source.

script.name: polarized_field.inr
script.title: Irradiance of Polarized Field
script.description: Irradiance of a polarized field. Demonstrates that orthogonally polarized fields sum in quadrature.

script.name: polariz_crystal.inr
script.title: Analyzing Crystal Polarizers
script.description: Using PLOT POLAR and LIST ELLIPSE to analyze a crystal-type polarizer. A CRYSTAL media generates two rays, ordinary and extraordinary.

script.name: polariz_list.inr
script.title: Numerical Analysis of Polarization
script.description: Using LIST ELLIPSE for numerical analysis of polarization.

script.name: POLARIZ_RANDOM_EMITTING_02.inr
script.title: Randomizing Polarization of Various Emitters
script.description: A set of all 14 EMITTING sources are created and displayed after setting a random polarization using the UNIFORM option. The user can choose which source to show the ray directions and polarization ellipses in the 3D viewer.

script.name: polar_lin_circular.inr
script.title: Linear to Circular Polarization
script.description: Linear polarized rays converted to circular polarization by an ideal lens. A grid of rays, initially linear polarized at 45Â° are passed through an ideal lens set up to be a quarter wave plate (using Jones Matrix - fast axis vertical). The result is right-circular polarization.

script.name: polar_qtr_wave.inr
script.title: Quarter Wave Plate using CRYSTAL
script.description: An example of birefringence through a crystal media. Shows how polarized light changes after propagating through a quarter wave plate made of Crystal media. PLOT POLARIZATION plots the two orthogonal linear polarization components. The FIELD commands allows study of the combined effects of the two rays.

script.name: Polar_Random_Emitter01.inr
script.title: Controlling Polarization of Emitters
script.description: Control polarization of emitters using POLARIZ RANDOM, and show the polarization in the 3D Viewer.

script.name: polar_rhomb.inr
script.title: Fresnel Rhomb Converter
script.description: The Fresnel rhomb is a simple optical device for converting linearly polarized light to circularly polarized light by way of total internal

script.name: polar_sapphire_dome.inr
script.title: Polarization of a Saphire Dome
script.description: An example of birefringence. How polarized light changes after propagating through a saphire dome. By specifying a CRYSTAL media with SPLIT set to 1, two independent rays are created from one input ray - the ordinary and extraordinary rays. PLOT POLARIZATION plots the two orthogonal linear polarization components. The FIELD commands allows study of the combined effects of the two rays.

script.name: polynomial_fit.inr
script.title: Polynomial Fit Model
script.description: Polynomial fit model of Chemglaze 306 data.

script.name: polynomial_fit02.inr
script.title: Polynomial Model Using Coefficients
script.description: Polynomial model of Chemglaze 306M. The coefficients used are a direct copy from a PRINT MODELS done on the POLYNOMIAL_FIT.INR. Note - commas must be added to continue lines.

script.name: print01.inr
script.title: Printing System Media
script.description: Example output of PRINT MEDIA for birefringent materials.

script.name: PRISM_ARRAY_BOUNDED_ROOFS.INR
script.title: Slanted Prism Array by Mutually Bounding TUBEs
script.description: An ARRAY of prisms created by using ROOF to form the main prism face, mutually bounded with a TUBE to form the sides and prism "heel". It traceS like a real surface, and a few periods are traced to show it works.

script.name: profiles01.inr
script.title: Plotting Profiles
script.description: Several examples of plotting with PROFILES is shown. PROFILES is dependent on previous WINDOW and PIXELS settings. The last example uses OBLIQUE setting.

script.name: PSF_Poly_Doublet01.inr
script.title: Polychromatic PSF of Discrete Lens
script.description: The following produces a Point Spread Function of an achromatic doublet made with discrete optical surfaces. Three wavelengths are summed incoherently at the target and plotted.

script.name: PSF_Poly_Doublet02.inr
script.title: Polychromatic PSF of Lens Sequence
script.description: The following produces a Point Spread Function of an achromatic doublet made with LENSES SEQUENCE command. Energy contributions from three wavelengths are incoherently summed at the target and plotted.

script.name: psf_poly_doublet03.inr
script.title: PSF and MTF of Doublet
script.description: Polychromatic PSF and MTF of a doublet lens.

script.name: ptf_poly_doublet.inr
script.title: Polychromatic PTF of Doublet
script.description: Polychromatic PTF of a doublet lens.

script.name: put01.inr
script.title: PUTing Ray Data
script.description: Transfers the current variable data to ray number 15 in the ray table. In this case ray 15 will be turned off because its FLUX will be set to zero.

script.name: racetrack01.inr
script.title: A Racetrack Edge
script.description: A full racetrack edge shown with PLOT EDGES.

script.name: Radial_Angles_Enclosed01.inr
script.title: Enclosed Energy vs. Angle #1
script.description: This shows a simple example of how to graph enclosed energy vs. angle out to 90 degrees using the $ITER command. It does not have the problem of spilling over 90 degrees when radially averaging over a rectangular map of angles - as when performing a RADIAL BOTH after converting dir-cosine data to angles.

script.name: Radial_Angles_Enclosed02.inr
script.title: Enclosed Energy vs. Angle #2
script.description: This is a more advanced example of how to graph enclosed energy vs. angle out to 90 degrees using the $ITER command. It does not have the problem of spilling over 90 degrees when radially averaging over a rectangular map of angles, as when performing a RADIAL BOTH after converting dir-cosine data to angles. This file compares both methods.

script.name: radiant01.inr
script.title: Radiance of Emitting Spheroid
script.description: Simple use of the RADIANT command. MESH allows viewing results in 3-D viewer.

script.name: radiant_area01.inr
script.title: Radiance of Multiple Emitting Spheroids
script.description: Plotting RADIANT AREA on multiple emitting spheroids of varying sizes. This is radiance per unit area in the plane of the selected window.

script.name: Radiant_Area_Anal.inr
script.title: Using SELECT ONLY to simulate RADIANT AREA
